channel.title: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge
channel.description:
If you learned something new (it doesn't have to have technically been [b]today[/b] but it has to have been a recent discovery) related to RSPS development then you can share it in this thread. You can share general Java knowledge, as well.
[u][b]Guidelines[/b][/u]
[ul][li]Explain (fully) what you learned and give an example of it.[/li] [li]Keep your explanation reasonably concise, it doesn't need to be a tutorial[/li] [li]Don't link to a tutorial and say "I learned how to do this"[/url][/ul]
I'll start the thread off: [b]Today I learned[/b] that the minimap colouring from team capes can be applied to any item via item definitions, although this will cause problems if a player wore a Team 1 Cape and a Team 2 Helmet.

item.title: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Scape-JAVA, post:304, topic:523919”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=642462.msg4458811#msg4458811 date=1416414542]

TIL about Java 8’s awesome forEach statements.

For example, following code:

ArrayList<Bullet> bullets = new ArrayList<>(); ArrayList<Player> players = getPlayers(); for (Player player : players) { for (Bullet bullet : player.getBullets()) bullets.add(bullet); } for (Player player : players) { for (Bullet bullet : bullets) { if (bullet.hitPlayer(player)) playerHit(player, bullet); } }
could be written like this:

players.forEach((player) -> player.getBullets().forEach(bullets::add) ); players.forEach((player) -> bullets.forEach((bullet) -> { if (bullet.hitPlayer(player)) playerHit(player, bullet); })); }

Another example:

for (Player player : getPlayers()) player.update();
to:

You’d want to be careful with using forEach, it can be restrictive. Most cases just stick with the for loop.
[/quote]

The only difference in a for each and a while loop is the syntax for defining them. The only actual difference is the for-each loop hides the ugly clutter and the opportunity by hiding the iterator/index value completely.[/quote]

No, thrown exceptions before the loops scope cannot be reached and non-effectively final variables cannot be modified within a Iterable#forEach loop, however both of these things can be done in a traditional for each or for index loop.

Read full topic
item.source: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge

item.title: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:301, topic:523919”][quote author=Snow_ link=topic=642462.msg4458627#msg4458627 date=1416312576]
TIL about Java 8’s awesome forEach statements.

For example, following code:

ArrayList<Bullet> bullets = new ArrayList<>(); ArrayList<Player> players = getPlayers(); for (Player player : players) { for (Bullet bullet : player.getBullets()) bullets.add(bullet); } for (Player player : players) { for (Bullet bullet : bullets) { if (bullet.hitPlayer(player)) playerHit(player, bullet); } }
could be written like this:

players.forEach((player) -> player.getBullets().forEach(bullets::add) ); players.forEach((player) -> bullets.forEach((bullet) -> { if (bullet.hitPlayer(player)) playerHit(player, bullet); })); }

Another example:

for (Player player : getPlayers()) player.update();
to:

[/quote]
You’d want to be careful with using forEach, it can be restrictive. Most cases just stick with the for loop.[/quote]

The only difference in a for each and a while loop is the syntax for defining them. The only actual difference is the for-each loop hides the ugly clutter and the opportunity by hiding the iterator/index value completely.

Read full topic
item.source: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge

item.title: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Ambokile:

Example pls

I can’t fix you a literal example, but you can’t do things like:

int i = 0;
players.forEach((player) ->
    ...
    i++;
);

You’d get a compiler error. I don’t think you can do any atomic operations.

There is no performance gain and forEach might execute in parallel. You also can’t handle exceptions.

But pros: People may argue that you get Limited flow-control but in reality that is exactly how a loop should be. No need for a premature break.

Read full topic
item.source: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge

Another example:

for (Player player : getPlayers()) player.update();
to:

[/quote]
You’d want to be careful with using forEach, it can be restrictive. Most cases just stick with the for loop.[/quote]
Example pls

item.title: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Snow_, post:295, topic:523919”]TIL about Java 8’s awesome forEach statements.

For example, following code:

ArrayList<Bullet> bullets = new ArrayList<>(); ArrayList<Player> players = getPlayers(); for (Player player : players) { for (Bullet bullet : player.getBullets()) bullets.add(bullet); } for (Player player : players) { for (Bullet bullet : bullets) { if (bullet.hitPlayer(player)) playerHit(player, bullet); } }
could be written like this:

players.forEach((player) -> player.getBullets().forEach(bullets::add) ); players.forEach((player) -> bullets.forEach((bullet) -> { if (bullet.hitPlayer(player)) playerHit(player, bullet); })); }

Another example:

for (Player player : getPlayers()) player.update();
to:

You’d want to be careful with using forEach, it can be restrictive. Most cases just stick with the for loop.

item.title: Today I learned! - Share your newfound knowledge
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:296, topic:523919”] players.forEach((player) -> bullets.forEach((bullet) -> { if (bullet.hitPlayer(player)) playerHit(player, bullet); })); }

->

players.forEach(player -> { bullets.stream().filter(bullet -> bullet.hitPlayer(player)).forEach(bullet -> playerHit(player, bullet)); }[/quote]

Could that not become:

players.forEach(player -> { bullets.stream().filter(Bullet::hitPlayer(player)).forEach(bullet -> playerHit(player, bullet)); }

Read full topic
